title: 114_s759
content: The Act titled "Expedited Consideration of Cuts, Consolidations, and Savings Act of 2015" introduces expedited consideration of cuts, consolidations, and savings prepared by the Office of Management and Budget. It amends Part B of title X of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The Act allows the President to transmit a special message to Congress within 120 days of a report by the Office of Management and Budget, to implement recommendations. The President can transmit a special message to Congress within 120 days of a report by the Office of Management and Budget, containing a draft bill or joint resolution to implement recommendations. The bill or joint resolution must be introduced in Congress by the majority or minority leaders within two days of the President's transmission. After a bill or joint resolution is transmitted to Congress, a Member of the Senate or House can introduce it if not already done so. The bill is then referred to the appropriate committee without substantive revision, which may report it with or without changes. After a bill is transmitted to Congress, it is referred to the appropriate committee for consideration. The committee must report the bill within a specified timeframe, or it will be discharged and referred to the House calendar for further action. In the House of Representatives, expedited consideration procedures are followed after the committee reports the bill. After a bill is reported or discharged for consideration in the House of Representatives, a motion to proceed to the bill is highly privileged, not debatable, with all points of order waived. The previous question is ordered on the motion without amendment. After a bill is reported or discharged for consideration in the House of Representatives, a motion to proceed to the bill is highly privileged, not debatable, with all points of order waived. The covered bill shall be considered as read, with the previous question ordered on its passage without intervening motion except for 4 hours of debate equally divided and controlled by the proponent and an opponent. A motion further to limit debate is in order and shall not be debatable. The covered bill shall not be amendable, and no motion to recommit or reconsider the vote is allowed. The vote on passage must occur immediately after debate and within ten days of introduction. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on House rules are permitted. Expedited consideration of covered bills in the House and Senate is governed by their respective rules without debate. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to consideration of a covered bill can be made after committee reports or discharge, bypassing Rule XXII. Expedited consideration of covered bills in the House and Senate is governed by their respective rules without debate. A motion to proceed to a covered bill waives all points of order, is not debatable, not subject to postponement, and amendments are not allowed. If agreed to, the covered bill remains unfinished. The Senate's consideration of a covered bill is limited to 10 hours divided equally between majority and minority leaders. Further debate limitations and motions are outlined, ensuring expedited processing without unnecessary delays. The debate on any debatable motion or appeal in connection with a covered bill is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill's manager. The vote on passage of a covered bill occurs immediately after the debate, with no opportunity for reconsideration of the vote. The debate on a covered bill is limited to 1 hour, with a single quorum call at the end if requested. Appeals on procedural rulings shall be decided without debate. Coordination with the other House on a covered bill is required before passage. The covered bill of the other House shall not be referred to a committee. The procedure in the receiving House shall be the same as if no covered bill had been received. If a covered bill is agreed to, it will be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House on the same day. The covered bill is to be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House on the same day. Rules for suspension of procedures in the Senate and House of Representatives are outlined, along with amendments to Section 904 and Section 1011 of the Act. Section 1014 is amended in paragraph (5) by replacing "1016" with "1017" and "1017(b)(1)" with "1018(b)(1)". Section 1015 is also amended to include references to "1014" in addition to "1012" and "1013". In subsection (e)(1), subparagraph (B) is redesignated as subparagraph (C) and references to "1013" are replaced with "1014". Additionally, a new subparagraph (B) is added requiring the transmission of a special message under section 1013 for a Cuts, Consolidations, and Savings report. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act. Title X of the Act is amended by redesignating sections 1013 through 1017 as sections 1014 through 1018 and adding a new item after section 1012. Section 1013 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions. This authority will terminate upon the sine die adjournment of Congress in 2018.
